repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
### Problem

Many plugins will want to take some action when the user performs a search. Currently there is no built-in hook for this.

### Solution

The SearchPost event will fire whenever a search is made.

### Context/Examples

- [nullromo/cash.nvim](https://github.com/nullromo/cash.nvim): this plugin would love this event because it would make setting up autocommands much easier.
- [tuurep/registereditor](https://github.com/tuurep/registereditor): this plugin displays what's in the "/ register in real time, so it would be nice to be able to hook into changes on that register.

### Current Workaround

Truly catching all search events requires mapping keys like `n` and `*` in normal and visual modes, as well as somehow detecting the `:substitute` command. This means multiple keymaps, and they could all potentially conflict with existing keymaps. The correct way to handle this is unclear.

## Checklist

#### Event triggers in the following situations

- [x] `n`/`N` from normal mode
- [x] `*`/`#` from normal mode
- [x] `n`/`N` from visual mode
- [x] `*`/`#` from visual mode
- [ ] `gd`, `gD` from normal mode
- [ ] `g*`, `g#` from normal mode
- [ ] `gd`, `gD` from visual mode
- [ ] `g*`, `g#` from visual mode
- [x] `:substitute`
- [ ] `:smagic`/`:snomagic`
- [ ] `:global`/`:vglobal`
- [ ] `:vimgrep`/`:vimgrepadd`/`:lvimgrep`/`:lvimgrepadd`
- [ ] `search()`
- [ ] `c_CTRL-T`/`c_CTRL-G`
- [ ] typing with `incsearch`

#### Other
- [ ] Data in `v:event` to determine source
- [ ] Data in `v:event` to determine peek

comment_regular_data.body: I don't think the failed checks are related to my changes.

Maybe other search family: https://github.com/kevinhwang91/nvim-hlslens/blob/1e650c136f9f9d5fefe34947ad27c80010d3321f/lua/hlslens/cmdline/parser.lua#L17-L25.

Isn't this also feasible with `CmdlineLeave` and `vim.api.nvim_parse_cmd`

> Maybe other search family

Can you please elaborate on what you mean?

> Isn't this also feasible with `CmdlineLeave`

[Yes](https://github.com/tuurep/registereditor/pull/12/files#diff-d810fdad6d4a47858eca196c5cf7e44065b1d9d5a0ab6f765a4526d59b1987baR66), you can catch that event and handle `:substitute`. But
a) it's inconvenient
b) it will fire unnecessarily on every cmdline command
c) it only covers `:substitute`, not <kbd>n</kbd>/<kbd>N</kbd>/<kbd>*</kbd>/<kbd>#</kbd>

> Can you please elaborate on what you mean?

Oh. I misread, in your case `:substitute` seems not considered as "search". (They are just some builtin commands that has `inccommand` feature)

Other cases like `search()`/`c_CTRL-T`/`c_CTRL-G` (not sure if they are "search")
No comment on whether this is wanted, but I suggest dropping `Post` from the name. If we ever need a "before" event then we would name it `SearchPre`, but the "Post" suffix is never needed.

@justinmk regarding the name, I originally had it as `Search`, but when I read `:h dev-name-events` it made me want to name it something like `{Noun}{Event}`. However, I now realize that `Post` is kind of a different thing. I tossed around some other ideas before, such as `SearchMade`, `SearchPerformed`, `SearchDone`, `TextSearched`, `SearchNext`, `SearchSearched`, ... Based on the rest of the event names in vim being two words, one of these or something else might be best. Anyway, I agree that `SearchPost` doesn't quite cut it. If anything it would be `SearchPerformedPost`, which as you said is not needed.

Though there are some events that are single words, namely `Signal`, `Syntax`, and `User`.

@phanen I see what you mean now. You're talking about how all the commands listed in that link will show search previews ("peek") as you type if incsearch is set. I do consider `:substitute` to be a search. Currently the event in this PR _does_ fire when using `:s`. My reasoning is that it changes the `"/` register. However, the incsearch stuff does not change the register, so I wasn't counting it as a search. Maybe there is room for yet another autocommand, like `IncSearch`. However, I think this distinction could be made with `v:event`. Do you think that would make sense? The `SearchPost` (or whatever it will be named) event could fire during incsearch, `c_CTRL-T`, and `c_CTRL-G`, as well as in the situations I already mentioned, but it would have a different `v:event` flag set depending on if it is a "peek" search or not.

> Maybe there is room for yet another autocommand, like `IncSearch`

Yeah. But this seems another complex topic. https://github.com/kevinhwang91/nvim-hlslens take efforts on this by parsing cmdline/keys... here's a way to get `IncSearch` without in core: 
```diff
diff --git a/lua/hlslens/cmdline/init.lua b/lua/hlslens/cmdline/init.lua
index 0e4693e..1f22d6e 100644
--- a/lua/hlslens/cmdline/init.lua
+++ b/lua/hlslens/cmdline/init.lua
@@ -67,6 +67,7 @@ function CmdLine:doRender(pos, endPos)
     if self.fold then
         self.fold:expand(pos[1])
     end
+    api.nvim_exec_autocmds('User', {pattern = 'IncSearch'})
 end
 
 ---may_do_incsearch_highlighting
```

Also there's user defined `:h command-preview`.



> My reasoning is that it changes the `"/` register

If so a `RegisterChanged` maybe another choice? It has a clear definition/pattern/data.
Isn't this something that can be upstreamed to Vim?

@yochem I wasn't sure what the right thing to do is.

1. I didn't see anything in [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) about how to handle vim vs. nvim development.
2. In the official vim repo, they say "If you create a pull request on GitHub it will be forwarded to the vim-dev mailing list." With all due respect to them it's overwhelming to try to learn a fourth-party method of contributing.
3. I noticed [vim_diff.txt](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/runtime/doc/vim_diff.txt) contains a number of events that are [not present in vim](https://vimhelp.org/autocmd.txt.html#autocmd-events-abc), which signals to me that there is a precedent for this.

If you have any advice, I would appreciate it.

No worries. If it's something Vim users can benefit of, and it is not Nvim-specific, it might be useful to submit a PR there. It'll probably best to first open an issue on vim/vim, proposing the new event and if such change is welcome. If the Vim team agrees, you can submit the PR there. If they don't want it, Nvim can consider adding it :).

So:
1. True, I would say it's generally "would this (small) addition benefit Vim users and does Vim welcome the change"
2. No need to worry about it. You can work via Github as usual.
3. That's right. Most of these (`UI*`, `Term*`, `Signal`) are Nvim-specific. The other ones, I'm not sure.

Ultimately, Nvim's core team should decide on this, but I think it wouldn't hurt to submit it to Vim first.
@yochem Thank you for the insight. I opened [an issue](https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/17791) there.
I realize now that I forgot `gd`, `gD`, `g*`, and `g#`. Adding a checklist to the PR description.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(events): add SearchPost event
